awd_titl_txt: Neural Circuits for the Executive Control of Action
awd_abstract_narration: This project will examine how neural activity in the medial frontal (or cingulate) cortex changes as new behavioral tasks are learned for the first time. The central issue is to understand how activity in this part of the brain allows for learning from past mistakes in order to avoid future failures. The experimental approach involves recording from chronically implanted arrays of electrodes in the medial frontal cortex of rats as the animals learn to perform reaction time tasks. These tasks are commonly used to study cognitive processing in human beings. The expected results will include testing a leading hypothesis in neuroscience that persistent activity in medial frontal cortex enables self-control, e.g. the ability to wait calmly before acting. We predict that this activity will develop in the medial frontal cortex during learning and will come to predict how well animals are able to adjust performance after mistakes are made. The potential impact of the study is that it will provide some of the first data on how error-related activity develops in this part of the brain during learning. Broader impact activities include data and computer resource sharing on a website, a multi-lingual children's program on the brain, and participation by undergraduates from a non-traditional research university in cutting-edge neurobiological research.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the role of the medial prefrontal cortex in executive control, for example, suppressing an inappropriate action. These issues were studied in a rodent model, which is increasingly used in biomedical research to understand the brain basis of many psychiatric and neurological diseases. The studies established that the rodent prefrontal cortex shows the same neuronal markers for executive processing as are found in the brains of higher primates and human beings. In addition, the project supported new studies that revealed a role of reward feedback in driving signaling by the medial prefrontal cortex, developed a novel computational model for performance monitoring (tracking behavioral outcomes to improve future performance), and implicated the norepinephrine system in the control of performance monitoring. The PI's lab was able to implement optogenetic methods with support from the project and nine research articles were published during the period of funding. The project also supported the graduate training of three PhD students (all women) and eight undergraduate students (including seven women) majoring in biology and neuroscience. Broader impact activities included a program on the brain for preschool children, an extension of that program to elementary and middle school age children, and supported the development of an on-line repository for sharing computer code and device designs for behavioral neuroscience research (the OpenBehavior project).
